Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the Mechanistic Basis and Adaptive Significance of the Coordination of Plant Growth by External and Internal Cues
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Stacey Harmer (University of California-Davis)
Co-PI: Ben Blackman (University of Virginia)

Plants optimize their use of local resources by synchronizing their growth with day/night cycles, resulting in daily rhythms in leaf, stem, and root growth. This coordination is accomplished through an intricate interplay between the light signaling, circadian clock, and hormone signaling networks. However, the manner in which these networks interact to control plant growth is poorly understood. This project exploits the robust ability of sunflower to track the sun to characterize pathways that coordinate plant growth with daily environmental fluctuations. First, developmental and environmental factors that control solar tracking will be defined. Next, high-throughput analysis of hormone and gene transcript levels in different portions of solar tracking stems will be carried out, allowing the identification of candidate genes and pathways controlling these growth rhythms. Finally, genome-enabled association and linkage mapping techniques will take advantage of the abundant natural variation present in common sunflower and its wild relatives to provide essential information about the role of solar tracking in plant adaptation to the environment. Together, these studies will elucidate the interactions between diverse signaling networks that optimize plant growth with environmental changes and provide insights into ways to improve plant performance.

Plant yield is enhanced by daily growth patterns of stems and leaves that allow more efficient photosynthesis and higher water use efficiency. Although a number of molecular pathways that regulate plant growth have been identified, an understanding of how they are coordinated with each other and with environmental cues remains elusive. Solar tracking in sunflower is an extremely appropriate trait for addressing these basic questions since it provides a unique entry point to determine how internal and external cues regulate growth across a single organ. By asking fundamental questions about how this coordination occurs and evolves, these studies will reveal important insights into how to enhance crop plant performance and conserve plant diversity in the face of global climate change and an increasing human population. In addition, this project will generate extensive resources that will be useful to the entire Compositae community. To provide public access to these resources, transcriptome and functionally annotated marker data will be deposited in public databases including the NCBI Short Read Archive (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra/), the Compositae Genome Project (http://compgenomics.ucdavis.edu/), the Sunflower Genome Resources Consortium (http://www.sunflowergenome.org), and DRYAD (http://datadryad.org/). Germplasm will be deposited with the National Plant Germplasm System (http://www.ars-grin.gov/npgs/). A student crowd-sourcing method will be developed for the analysis of time-lapse videos of plants grown in natural and controlled environments. This image analysis software developed with the iPlant Collaborative will be made freely available via the iPlant Phytobisque web portal (https://pods.iplantcollaborative.org/wiki/display/ipg2p/PhytoBisque). Finally, cross-disciplinary training in genomic, ecological, and quantitative approaches will be provided for the undergraduate and graduate students and post-doctoral fellows involved in these studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants modify their growth to optimize their ability to capture light and carry out photosynthesis. One spectacular example of this optimization is solar tracking or heliotropism in which plants bend their leaves and stems during the course of the day to track the sun’s apparent movement across the sky. While many plant species are heliotropic, this behavior is perhaps most obvious in domesticated sunflower, with its single large stem and composite flower. Remarkably, young sunflower plants not only bend from east to west during the day to follow the sun but also bend back from west to east during the night in anticipation of dawn.  Solar tracking movements gradually decline as plants reach maturity until at the time of flower opening daily bending movement cease and flower heads face uniformly east. We have used a combination of physiological, genomic, and quantitative genetics approaches to understand the underlying mechanisms controlling solar tracking and its importance for vegetative and reproductive growth. This work has helped elucidate interactions between diverse signaling networks that optimize plant growth in response to internal and environmental cues.

Project Outcomes

We demonstrated that daily solar tracking movements enhance plant growth, leading to increases in leaf area and biomass. Detailed studies in the field and in controlled environmental conditions revealed that a key regulator of solar tracking movements is the plant circadian clock, the internal oscillator that coordinates daily rhythms in many essential biological activities. These daily bending rhythms are generated by oppositely-phased growth patterns on the east and west sides of stems. Analysis of gene expression patterns in east- and west-facing segments of the growing stem over time has suggested that the plant growth hormone auxin plays a critical role in generating these differential growth patterns. In related work, we found that the uniform eastward orientation of flowering sunflower plants is due to clock-regulation of plant sensitivity to light, with maximal bending responses to directional light occurring in the morning.  This eastward orientation allows flowers to warm up quickly in the morning, enhancing visits from pollinating insects. We have also demonstrated that east-facing flowers sire more offspring than west-facing controls.  Thus, modulation of directional stem growth by the clock to control final head orientation is evolutionarily adaptive. 

Broader Impacts

Plants must coordinate how they grow over time to take advantage of and cope with with daily cycles in the availability and quality of resources in the natural environment. Our research provides a greater understanding of the mechanisms by which internal and environmental signals regulate growth pathways to achieve this coordination in a spatially complex manner in an important oilseed crop species. In doing so, our work provides entry points for plant breeders to improve crop growth and inspiration from the natural world for engineers seeking to solve similar light capture and architectural design challenges.

In the course of our experiments, we have also generated substantial resources for the sunflower research community. These resources include abundant genomic data capturing daily rhythms in gene expression as well as genetic material that may be used to identify novel gene variants affecting other essential agronomic traits.

During the course of the grant, five post-doctoral scholars, five graduate students, two post-baccalaureate technicians, 76 undergraduate students, and 12 high school students received training in scientific research.  This set of trainees includes 16 students who are members of groups underrepresented in science and 57 women.  Undergraduate and post-baccalaureate alumni have gone on to doctoral programs in biology (14), positions in biotech industry (8), or other graduate or professional programs in STEM fields (5).  One former post-doctoral fellow is now in a tenure-track faculty position and a former graduate student is now carrying out post-doctoral research.
